name: Vintage Folk
description:
With tribal inspiration these hand picked vintage fabrics have been remodelled to create some Eastern Soul magic. Scouring through piles of fabrics I searched for craftsmanship,  history and colour to create pieces that tell stories of gypsy travel, culture and art.

Each panel chosen was originally a Galla, which was used by Banjara woman to cover the nape of their neck and they date back around 70 years. With embroidery taking months to complete each piece is hand stitched with geometric patterns and finished with the typical Banjara mirror work, coin embellishment and cowrie shells making it a completely individual piece.

description:

With exotic silver carving and the beauty of the unique Tibetan Dzi this baby is a striking piece for the earthy goddess. With ancient techniques employed a timeless piece with cultural edge.

name: Lingam Container
description:
Dating back from the early 12th century Lingam containers are connected to the Lingayat sect of India. They are a three-piece item, the base is commonly decorated with floral motifs coming to a point that represents a flower bud. The second piece or the centrepiece also with floral motifs has two rectangular shaped sides that are usually strung with a chain or cord for it then to be suspended around the neck. 

This piece is known as a Jangama lingam as inside would usually hold a sacred piece of carved stone that would be coated in a protective ash, clay and wax. The Lingayat people would wear this symbol their entire life, for it to be then buried with them in their left hand, as they believe it to be the only true symbol of Shiva. This piece however, dates approximately 18-19th century. It has been newly strung onto a chain and it is empty allowing you to put any keepsake inside. A truly special piece, with traces of history and symbolism, that reminds us of what jewellery is all about. 

- Silver 
- Chain: Length 15” Each Side
- Lingam Container: Length 50mm / Width 50mm
- Postage includes insurance in case lost or damaged

description:
Tribal jewellery is very much present within the Naga culture. Each piece having a strong sense of symbolism, they are worn to tell a story of a person’s life and all their experiences. It was prevalent around 60 years ago within Naga culture to head hunt, it was only when a man has seized a human head could he tattoo his face and wear a brass necklace representing this. The Naga people believe that a human skull was needed to ensure fertility of their people and crops.

name: The Lonesome Naga
description:
Tribal jewellery is very much present within the Naga culture. Each piece having a strong sense of symbolism, they are worn to tell a story of a person’s life and all their experiences. It was prevalent around 60 years ago within Naga culture to head hunt, it was only when a man has seized a human head could he tattoo his face and wear a brass necklace representing this. The Naga people believe that a human skull was needed to ensure fertility of their people and crops.

- Brass, Shell, Clay & Glass beads
- Length 373mm
- Brass Head:  Length 62mm / Width 50mm

name: Rabari
description:
This original 20th century Amulet container is statement of gypsy art. Like its wearer this piece tells a story of its journey through the harsh landscape of Gujarat and has darkened, curved and aged like the Rabari woman who wore it. Its robust and decorative silver work spreads from the carefully pointed ends to the five ornate bails that centre it. The floral motifs extend down to the six sets of tassels that joyfully dance as it is worn. Traditionally strung on black cord this piece was designed never to be removed, as the hollow compartment that lay inside held prayers of protection. It was also a symbol of a woman’s caste and her place within the tribe in which she was born. An absolute stunning piece with a world of history and beauty connected to it.

TIBETAN DZI
Dzi is a Tibetan word meaning “Good retribution, dignity and perfection”, believed to be a supernatural stone created from the gods it is rare and valuable in Tibet and sometimes valued above diamonds. Considered to be lucky, bringing good fortune and protection from evil and physical harm.

With an indigenous appearance this Tibetan wonder is completely unique. The hand carved silver setting coats the finger with tribal embellishment to be finished with an earthy Dzi stone. The milky white lines of history contain flecks of orange and with the rich brown outline this stone absolutely special. 

- Sterling Silver Stamped 92.5 & Natural Tibetan Dzi

name: Moon Wanderer Two
description:
RAINBOW MOONSTONE
Commonly used in ancient and contemporary tribal jewellery Rainbow Moonstone is known for its talent for individuality and beauty. Scientifically known as “White Labradorite” its streaks of blue, purple and gold allow you to look deeply into the stones layers to only keep finding more splendors this called the “schiller effect”. Being frequently used during meditation and visualization as this stone is thought to release creativity and aid clarity. However in ancient times the Indians believed that during a full moon Rainbow Moonstone would contain magical powers to provide good fortune.

This ornately carved statement ring is the go-to piece for any gypsy chick. The triangular shaped stone is the perfect centerpiece for this contemporary Nepali embellished band.

- Sterling Silver & Natural Rainbow Moonstone
- Adjustable Band: From 10.5 US

name: Cleo Two
description:
LAPIS LAZULI
Dating back 3100BC this magical stone was used among the Egyptians for jewellery, sculptures and when crushed up even cosmetics. Not only does its beautiful color shine desire, it is suggested to be the stone for friendship, truth and self-awareness. There are many sources of Lapis Lazuli in the world but Afghanistan holds the major deposits and is still currently used as a sacred stone among their culture.

The deep blue color perfectly covered in pyrite flecks of gold makes this piece twinkle like the night sky. The beauty of this natural stone is complemented with the typical Eastern Soul filigree that coats the finger into a Lush tribal statement.

name: Maha Ganesh
description:
GANESHA
The son of Shiva and Parvati, Lord Ganesha is a Hindu Deity that is worshiped as the Lord of success, destroyer of evil and remover of obstacles. He is the god of knowledge, wisdom and wealth and is one of the five prime deities in Hinduism.

This beautiful piece of wearable art is full of symbolism and craftsmanship. The simple yet slick silver setting allows the intricately hand painted image stand forth and tell its story. In this piece Lord Ganesh sits holding two lotus flowers which represents beauty and non attachment, he also holds a cloth with which legends narrate that Ganesh broke his tusk to use as a tool to scribe the epic Mahabharata, to teach that no sacrifice is big enough in the pursuit of knowledge.

-	Sterling silver Stamped 92.5
-	Hand painted artwork encased in plastic
-	Length of ring: 38mm / width 30mm
